body:
@ncw , version v1.42-030-ge24fe271  doesn't seem to fix it:

```
[...]
018/07/11 15:28:02 INFO  :
Transferred:      0 Bytes (0 Bytes/s)
Errors:                 0
Checks:                 0
Transferred:            0
Elapsed time:        3m0s

2018/07/11 15:28:05 DEBUG : pacer: Rate limited, increasing sleep to 20
ms
2018/07/11 15:28:05 DEBUG : pacer: low level retry 1/10 (error -> githu
b.com/ncw/rclone/vendor/github.com/Azure/azure-storage-blob-go/2017-07-
29/azblob.NewResponseError, /home/travis/gopath/src/github.com/ncw/rclo
ne/vendor/github.com/Azure/azure-storage-blob-go/2017-07-29/azblob/zz_g
enerated_response_error.go:29
===== RESPONSE ERROR (ServiceCode=) =====
Description=failed to read response body, Details: (none)
   GET https://XXXX.blob.core.windows.net/XXXX?com
p=list&delimiter=&include=metadata&maxresults=5000&restype=container&ti
meout=61
   Authorization: REDACTED
   User-Agent: [Azure-Storage/0.1 (go1.10.1; linux)]
   X-Ms-Client-Request-Id: [XXXXXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXX-XXXXXXXXX]
   X-Ms-Date: [Wed, 11 Jul 2018 19:27:26 GMT]
   X-Ms-Version: [2017-07-29]
   --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   RESPONSE Status: 200 OK
   Content-Type: [application/xml]  
   Date: [Wed, 11 Jul 2018 19:27:31 GMT]
   Server: [Windows-Azure-Blob/1.0 Microsoft-HTTPAPI/2.0]
   X-Ms-Request-Id: [7ccc4720-501e-0004-694d-1968da000000]
   X-Ms-Version: [2017-07-29]


read tcp XX.XX.XX.XX:58454->XX.XX.XX.XX:443: read: connection reset by peer
)
2018/07/11 15:32:02 INFO  :
Transferred:      0 Bytes (0 Bytes/s)
Errors:                 0
Checks:                 0
Transferred:            0
Elapsed time:        7m0s

2018/07/11 15:33:02 INFO  :
Transferred:      0 Bytes (0 Bytes/s)
Errors:                 0
Checks:                 0
Transferred:            0
Elapsed time:        8m0s

Transferred:      0 Bytes (0 Bytes/s)
Errors:                 0
Checks:                 0
Transferred:            0
Elapsed time:        9m0s


2018/07/11 15:34:49 DEBUG : pacer: Rate limited, increasing sleep to 80ms
2018/07/11 15:34:49 DEBUG : pacer: low level retry 3/10 (error -> github.com/ncw/rclone/vendor/github.com/Azure/azure-storage-blob-go/2017-07-29/azblob.NewResponseError, /home/travis/gopath/src/github.com/ncw/rclone/vendor/github.com/Azure/azure-storage-blob-go/2017-07-29/azblob/zz_generated_response_error.go:29

```
I added the command line option in https://github.com/ncw/rclone/compare/master...scollazo:wip/configure-azure-chunk-list-size?expand=1 ,  but not sure if it's worth a PR, or you want to take another approach

@scollazo - I tried to repro this with directory containing 10K files, each file of 1K size and I was able to copy without any issues
```console
Transferred:   9.767 MBytes (48.452 kBytes/s)
Errors:                 0
Checks:                 0
Transferred:        10001
Elapsed time:     3m26.4s

2018/07/11 19:53:20 DEBUG : 15 go routines active
2018/07/11 19:53:20 DEBUG : rclone: Version "v1.42-DEV" finishing with parameters ["rclone" "copy" "--fast-list" "-vv" "~/tmpfiles/" "azblob:tmp2"]

```
Do you think it is something specific on client side? 

```console
rclone v1.42-DEV
- os/arch: linux/amd64
- go version: go1.8.3
```
Either way having configurable value might be good option as well, if you and Nick are fine, I can pull your changes into my PR addressing #2371

This is only happening in one of my environments, I did some tests, and it failed with a folder with 30k files between 2 kilobytes and 4 megabytes, but I can't rule out problems client side.

Using my modified version, I was able to sync ~700k files without issues.

If @ncw agrees, I'm fine with this being part of #2371

I don't really understand why changing the chunk size from 5000 to 1000 fixes it?  Is it because of some internal timeout at Azure meaning that the longer listing fails?

Is this actually an Azure issue?

The docs say [5000 should be OK](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/storageservices/list-blobs) so I'm puzzled.

I think we are hitting another Azure limit: 

> Calls to get a blob, get page ranges, or get a block list are permitted 2 minutes per megabyte to
> complete. If an operation is taking longer than 2 minutes per megabyte on average, it will time out.

From https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/storageservices/setting-timeouts-for-blob-service-operations

I think that listing in smaller chunks allows the request to finish without reaching the 2mb/minute timeout

> The docs say 5000 should be OK so I'm puzzled.

Correct, it should work listing or copying easily with 5K, I tried `lsl` after copying objects to azure and it seems to work fine. Looks like something else is masking issue here, perhaps file names are longer, http request/response getting truncated or timed out at some place?

Looking at the link @scollazo posted it looks like we could set the `timeout` URL parameter.

    GET https://myaccount.blob.core.windows.net?comp=list&timeout=20

How long are the requests taking at the moment - are they 30 seconds or less?  I can't see what the default timeout is.  I think it might set the timeout to the max of 30 seconds as it is.

You can see if you use `-vv --dump headers` and look at the timestamps.

Is there still interest in this?  It would be easy to make a `--azure-list-chunk` flag / config setting if required (all backend config flags can be set in the config file now)

@scollazo Maybe you could send a PR with that in?
This is happening in other of my test servers, I'll work on it.
